newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: FORECAST-Austria's Wifo sees 97 growth at 1.2 pct.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST-Austria's Wifo sees 97 growth at 1.2 pct.

text.p: Austria's top economic research body Wifo said on Thursday it is sticking to its forecast that Austria's economy would grow by a real 1.2 percent in 1997.
"I cannot offer you something better at moment", Wifo chief Helmut Kramer told a conference on Thursday.
Wifo, on whose forecasts the Austrian government bases its policies, has forecast next year's growth of gross domestic product (GDP) at 2.2 percent.
The Organisation for Economic Development and Cooperation (OECD) earlier on Thursday forecast GDP growth at 1.4 percent this year and at 2.3 percent in 1998.
Kramer said growth was backed by exports which were expected to grow six percent this year.
Austria's economy would continue to depend heavily on Germany, he said, adding that recent fourth-quarter data had not supported the assumption that the German economy would pick up in 1997.
Wifo expects the German economy to grow by between two and 2.5 percent this year, he said.

Kramer also warned against postponing the start of Europe's planned economic and monetary union (EMU). "I doubt whether a structured delay would be possible", he said, and forecast grave turbulences on financial markets if the project was delayed.
"The idea of a single currency would probably be discredited for years", he said.
In a study released last week, Wifo said the single currency would bring Austria additional growth of up to 2.25 percent over a five-year period.
"EMU is an investment in Europe's future", Kramer said. -- Christian Gutlederer, Vienna newsroom +431 53112-275
